content: Before we get started, how's everyone been?
Hi everyone, I'll be reading along today!
So, we don't have anything in particular planned for today
I'm super excited to put more thoughts into traits I have to say. And a bit afraid that with all going it'll be hard as usual, but I hope to make time. :)
But we should probably recap what's happened over the summer
yeah I've still got 386 unread zulip messages from summer
so I'd like to get an overview of what's going on :)
I'm super excited to see some things move forward. Really want to see Chalk integration in rustc move forward
...I may just "mark all as read" I guess..
I would like to see like 40-60% of rustc tests pass in compare mode=chalk
Anyways, the past month or two hasn't been super active
/me goes to look what's happened in rustc first

I thnk a good goal for the meeting would be surveying where we are, maybe re-establishing a bit the overall status of things -- I've had a long-standing project to update the skill tree, which might be a good goal for this week
maybe we should take some notes just on the general status of the things we were working on
So, looking at the sprint doc (thanks @detrumi for posting)
(for those who are new, the skill tree kind of tracks some of the major milestones and progress towards them, though it's a bit out of date)
I'm not sure going over all the past goals is best
But maybe bring up things that haven't been finished
where is the meeting agenda doc that we had before?
just to have a place to take notes that is not the old sprint doc
We did a poor job of keeping that updated near the end of last sprint
I think going through active/recent work first is a better ordering than going through the whole list
I guess let's start with rustc integration?
since @Jack Huey brought it up?
I am taking some notes in this hackmd, maybe people can add some other things that have had updates in the bullet list
I put that into the bullet list
I think I can do that tomorrow morning
I thought it was still blocked on some tings on the chalk side, but I guess not?
Nope, nothing Chalk side is blocking it
I have/had a WIP branch based on the variance work in chalk
once that PR lands, what are the next steps towards chalk-rustc integration? is it the variance work
I don't know what else really can/should be done there (except for maybe generators when they come) that's not "major"
Is there open work available on rustc's side for getting compare-mode=chalk to pass more tests, or is it mainly chalk changes?
Regions/Lifetime work somewhat, but I think that's rustc
@detrumi yeah, that's what I'm saying, there might be smaller things to do (like Foreign and such), but overall it's blocked on Chalk
we definitely have to do work towards unifiying rustc's Ty<'tcx> and chalks Ty<I> for the integration to truly work I think
We either need to refactor out Param on rustc side, add it to Chalk, or decide on a "permanent" way to reconcile the two
so I guess that bleeds into the next topic
I sort of view the param treatment as being part of that discussion
the overall idea being that there is a bullet for "align how rustc and chalk represents types"
anyway it is all coming (painfully) back to me now
in particular I remember that we were discussing a bit whether to adopt the rustc representation (where we don't know how many parameters a binder binds) etc
we should also link to tracking issues where they exist
also for new folks, we have this repo https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits
although it's not that well populated right now
we should probably have a rustc-chalk integration issue too
From what I can see, that looks good to me to merge
however I think this version still has kind() -> &TyData and we were debating about refactoring that to kind() -> TyData, right?
Certainly @lcnr was advocating for it
I left you a message about that in another topic by the way, maybe you missed it
I think merging a kind() -> &TyData then maybe &TyData -> TyDatais probably a better way to approach
Since having &TyData doesn't break anything and doesn't affect perf
The problem is that since we're copying the TyKind, there are some problems with ownership if we want to return references
I'd be ok landing the PR as is
we can revisit it, as @Jack Huey says
although I don't quite understand the problem so I guess @LeSeulArtichaut I should find that message :)
Right, please tell me if you want me to try to still try to do more changes
Yes. Did I mess up my previous link?
On the Chalk side, I think we only need to add Generators and extern types
no, niko just missed it again :smirk:
I just changed the topic btw to something more descriptive
OK, anyway, let's note this and move on, but I will get back to you @LeSeulArtichaut on that
I see the problem now, for now I'm kind of inclined to land as is
oh, I thought the links would persist, too bad
And traits that need to be added on Chalk side: Unpin, CoerceUnsized, and DispatchFromDyn
I guess the other thing in this heading then is figuring out how to manage bound variables
ah, that's another bullet item I guess?
do we have a chalk tracking issue for that?
In my mind, I sometimes lump that into the region/lifetime work
Don't know if @Areredify is still working on that
(but there was maybe a pending PR from @Areredify ?)
I see there are also a few lingering builtin types to add, I guess we mentioned them earlier
would be nice for rust-analyzer I think
(cc @Aaron Hill, still working on generator witness types?)
generators enable support for async in RA
There is a WIP PR for that
so I guess that's another thing we could turn to a bit, looking at filed issues and PRs
I was skimming now and I saw various interesting ones :)
definitely gonna get there Niko, just not yet :)
Still gotta get through things not finished :)
Is there anything that needs to be done?
Or is it just optimizations w/ salsa
I saw some filed issues that seemed relevant
I think I'm ready to retract the PR on negative cycles for now in the hopes we never need them
Yeah that canonical vs instantiated program clause generation is a tricky one
yeah I wish I could remember all the details
we could try to schedule a time (e.g., a meeting) to talk it over
but probably not for a few weeks
Yeah, I'm not sure we ever fully explored the considerations for each
so I was writing up some docs
oh right, I tried to finish those docs but couldn't push to niko's branch or something
I think chalk#579 is just waiting for Niko's r+
Then, other than docs, is the WF rules with implied bounds
Can someone maybe elaborate on that last point somewhere? (maybe the tracking issue)
I'll assign that to you @detrumi :P
in general there was this question around implied bounds, right, i.e., whether to match how rustc worked ..
Ah yes, auto traits w/ builtin types for Chalk
(I'm amazed on how there seems to be a whole agenda in Jack's head)
not sure the best place to put that
quick question, @detrumi, you had fixes for chalk#559? I can give you access to my chalk fork
I'm somewhat going by the last sprint goals
... this seems like a good starter issue
Related is builtin traits with builtin types
we have some table kind of tracking this progress, right?
if that's true, though, we're largely up to date
basically only types that are not implemented
Running pretty low on time, let's move on
New open working PR by @Nathan Whitaker
I'm adding these to my "to do list", not sure how much I'll be able to do tomorrow but hopefully by end of week
But I'm not super sure what else to do
Any reason we can't land projections only at first
(Functions too now, just pushed that a bit ago)
The main issue is I tested the changes out on rust-analyzer, and it causes some non-insignificant performance regressions
Okay, now we can go through any other open PRs
Variance/subtyping. @Super Tuple and @David Ross said they want to take a look at this
(I don't have a ton of time)
The big thing here is coming up with tests and porting the Generalizer from rustc
But probably need some input from Niko

Jack Huey said:

But probably need some input from Niko

is there a topic for me to catch up on or something
For negative cycles, if there is a bug, we should maybe sure that we don't give wrong results, though I don't think we should give any results for negative cycles

Re variance, we've got it rebased and have been looking at the generalizer, but having a hard time coming up with generalizer test cases. I think we should be able to port it, but don't really understand how it's necessary in chalk
@David Ross I should be able to help with that

David Ross said:

Re variance, we've got it rebased and have been looking at the generalizer, but having a hard time coming up with generalizer test cases. I think we should be able to port it, but don't really understand how it's necessary in chalk

Yeah, that was somewhat were I left off. i.e. needing tests
it mostly doesn't come up in chalk but it can
at least if we're doing it right

Jack Huey said:

For negative cycles, if there is a bug, we should maybe sure that we don't give wrong results, though I don't think we should give any results for negative cycles

say more about this?
or are you referencing my PR and concerns?
Super low on time, so I want to move on
one small nit for @Nathan Whitaker then r+able

Jack Huey said:

one small nit for Nathan Whitaker then r+able

being fixed as we speak it seems :tada:
So, does everyone still like the sprint system?
lots of time, but I think I'm still a fan
um, let's decide on that next meeting? we can probably start a sprint then if we want
yeah, seems like it'd be better to call it here, we did an impressive sweep
I was mostly gonna say: let's plan to plan next meeting

my main comment on the sprint system is that, while I think it's useful, I do wonder if we can focus on fewer items -- but somehow there always seems to be some creep that causes us to grow the number of items
but maybe we can start out trying to be focused :)
Well, another thing is that we're starting to get blocked a just a couple hard things
or center some goals around 1-3 main goals
versus in the beginning of the year, there was a lot of smaller things
hopefully we can have some renewed energy to fix that
Sometime before next week, I'll make a topic to start to put together ideas for next sprint
One more potential action item for niko: work on the skill tree?
I'm trying to keep the list of things for Niko to do small
